If the human body needs food and drink, then the spirit, soul, and mind also need food and drink. Both are done during sleep. Sleep is nothing but a shackle for the body, but freedom for the soul. Thus, the psychological aspect finds its happiness during sleep, and is free from materiality, pressure, and injustice. If not, the spirit will always be shackled in the body and its light will fade.

People who consider sleep as a trivial matter, a heavy and obligatory necessity for the human body, and a medicine that grips their personality, as in childhood and old age, such assumptions are because they only know what can be touched by hand or seen with their own eyes. As for what is behind that, they do not know or believe it, or because they are materialistic, who only look at matter. They associate with humans only on the basis of matter.

If sleep is considered a real blessing, then Allah has provided the night as the right time for it. Sleep is a clear blessing, as in Allah's word:

Say, "Have you considered: if Allah should make continuous the day over you until the Day of Resurrection, what god other than Allah could bring you a night in which you may rest? Then will you not see?" (al-Qashash/28: 72)

The night is like a curtain that covers living creatures, including humans. Then it leads them to tranquility, then to sleep.

Indeed, the night is inevitable, as is the day. Night is a time for rest and day is a time for work. As for those who work at night, they are still required to maintain the rights of their bodies in the sense of resting them. Allah says:

And it is He who takes your souls by night and knows what you have committed by day. Then He revives you therein that a specified term may be fulfilled. Then to Him will be your return; then He will inform you about what you used to do. (al-Anam/6: 60)

Because night is an important and appropriate time for sleep, Allah swears many times in the Qur'an by the night, such as Surah al-Lail (The Night), as an appreciation for the night time. In this surah, there is an indication that when the night comes, the light of day is covered, and there is widespread darkness and silence. Such a time is perfect for the body and soul to sleep and rest. When day comes, the universe is bright and such a time is very appropriate for working, striving, and struggling. Allah says:

By the night when it covers, and [by] the day when it appears in brightness. (al-Lail/92: 1-2)

In another verse, Allah says:

By the sun and its brightness, and [by] the moon when it follows it, and [by] the day when it displays it, and [by] the night when it covers it. (asy-Syams/91: 1-4)

In verse 23, the day is equated with the night, namely with His word, "…your sleep by night and day." This is to emphasize that night, although the right time for sleep, does not prohibit people from using the day for sleep. In general, people sleep at night, but not a few of them sleep during the day, or part of their sleep is carried out during the day. Therefore, the night is mentioned first.

This verse closes with the expression, "Indeed in that are signs for a people who listen." In this expression, the call is addressed to hearing, not other senses. This is an indication that hearing creates knowledge, and also gives the understanding that sleeping at night and day, and striving to seek Allah's bounty are part of the signs of His power and greatness. Only people who have sharp and sensitive hearing can pay attention to what they hear, especially the verses of the Qur'an that are recited to them.
text.24:
This verse explains other signs of Allah's power and greatness, namely lightning. This is a natural phenomenon that can be witnessed by the senses and can also be explained scientifically. Lightning arises from electrical sparks that occur when positive electricity in a group of clouds containing water unites with negative electricity on the earth, when the two are close together, for example when the cloud is at the top of a mountain. From the union of these two types of electricity arises an air discharge that results in lightning, followed by thunder, and rainfall. So lightning is a natural phenomenon that arises from the rules created by God to regulate this universe.

The Qur'an, in accordance with its nature as a book of da'wah, does not detail the essence of natural phenomena, and does not explain the causes. The Qur'an only mentions it as a tool to connect the hearts of humans with nature and its Creator. Therefore, in this verse, He establishes one of the signs of Allah's existence, namely by showing the state of lightning that causes fear and hope. These two instinctive feelings come alternately to the human soul in the face of this phenomenon.

The feeling of fear arises when seeing lightning because it is followed by thunder that, if it strikes something, will destroy it. If a human is struck by it, he will die burned. If metal is struck, then the object will melt. If stone and buildings are struck, they will be destroyed.

After the words fear and hope, this verse continues with "He sends down water (rain) from the sky, then with that water He gives life to the earth after it is dead (dry)." The expression of life and death, when connected with the earth, is an expression that describes that the earth can live and can also die. That is the reality depicted by the Qur'an. This universe is a living creature, which is submissive and obedient to Allah, carrying out His commands by glorifying and worshiping Him. Humans who live on earth are one of Allah's creatures. They, along with these creatures, are in a great parade facing Allah, the Lord of the universe.

In addition, when water irrigates the soil, it will fertilize it. Then plants grow and their leaves develop. Likewise with animals and humans. Water is a messenger and bearer of life. Where there is water, there is life.

Indeed, in that are signs of Allah's power for a people who use their minds. This verse ends with the word "mind," as a medium for thinking and investigating.
text.25:
This verse explains that among the other signs of Allah's power are the heavens without supporting pillars and the round earth without any foundation piles. The existence of the heavens and the earth by the will of Allah implies that their existence remains under His protection and arrangement. By the will of Allah (bi amrihi) here means His power and ability. If someone argues that the universe, both the heavens and the earth, has existed in such a way according to its nature, without being maintained by Allah, what about their opinion of the very harmonious natural laws, so that one with the other never collides. Some people deny that this universe is Allah's creation and is under His protection because they do not want to acknowledge His oneness. The heavens and the earth will remain in their present state until a predetermined time comes, namely the occurrence of the Day of Judgment (Kiamat). When that time comes, humans will answer the call of God to rise from the grave.

When the day of resurrection will come is unknown to anyone. One thing is clear: the call to resurrection comes after all humans have died. The expression "immediately you will come forth (from the graves)" indicates that the resurrection from the graves is immediately after the call, not delayed even for a moment. Allah says in another verse:

Then the trumpet will be blown, and at once they will come forth from the graves to their Lord. (Yasin/36: 51)

The words "immediately" or the words "suddenly" in verse 25 are addressed to those who do not want the Day of Resurrection and do not believe in the Hereafter. Therefore, it can be understood that when they are resurrected on the Day of Judgment (Kiamat), they are astonished and amazed. Then they say as narrated in the Qur'an:

They will say, "Woe to us! Who has raised us up from our sleeping place?" [The reply will be], "This is what the Most Merciful had promised, and the messengers told the truth." (Yasin/36: 52)
text.26:
This verse is a conclusion to the verses above. It means that such is the power and greatness of God. Whatever is in the heavens and on earth belongs to Him and is subservient to Him. However, most people do not submit and do not worship Him. Therefore, the decree in this verse means the submission of everything in the heavens and on earth to the will and desire of Allah. His will controls everything in accordance with the *sunnah* that He has determined. In this regard, everything is subject to that *sunnah*, even though some people are disobedient and deny in their actions and deeds. Indeed, what is disobedient is their intellect and their hearts. As for the body, they are submissive and regulated according to the laws of nature, which are called *sunnatullah*. Allah says:

"Do they seek other than the religion of Allah, while to Him has submitted [all] that is in the heavens and the earth, willingly or by compulsion, and to Him they will be returned?" (ali 'Imran/3: 83)

Furthermore, the verses regarding the evidence of God's greatness above are concluded with a warning about the Day of Resurrection, because it is forgotten by people.
text.27:
This verse is also a conclusion from the previous verse. This verse establishes that He who possesses all the heavens and the earth, He is the One who initiated their creation, and He is also the One who will return them after death as they were originally.

In verse 11 above, the beginning of human creation and its return to life after death have been mentioned. This is repeated here to strengthen that statement after the evidence of Allah's greatness has been explained above. Here, it is added with the statement that reviving is easier for Him. In this verse, there are the words "easier," meaning that reviving is easier for Allah than creating it initially. However, the ease of reviving compared to creating all of that is by comparing it to the habits that apply to humans, not related to Allah, because for Allah, everything is easy. Allah will not feel burdened to create anything. Allah says:

"Indeed, His command is when He intends a thing, He says to it, "Be," and it is." (Yasin/36: 82)

For humans, creating something is more difficult than repeating all the efforts, seriousness, and so on. In their efforts, they make mistakes repeatedly, only then reaching what is intended. After reaching what is aspired to, of course, repeating its creation is easier for them, not requiring energy like when starting it, because everything has been imagined in their minds how to make it. As for Allah, there is nothing easier or more difficult. Everything is easy for Him.

Allah swt said, "The son of Adam has lied to Me and insulted Me, even though the lie and insult never existed. As for their lie against Me, it is their saying, 'Allah cannot return me as He created me.' And there is no beginning of creation that is easier for Me than returning it. As for their insult against Me, it is their saying, 'Allah takes (has) a son.' And I am One, the One upon whom all depend, I neither beget nor was I begotten, nor is there to Me any equivalent." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah)

The words "easier" are also commented on with the sentence "He possesses the most exalted attribute in the heavens and the earth." Allah is unique in all the heavens and the earth with all His attributes, there is nothing that associates with Him. There is nothing like Him. He is the All-Mighty, the All-Wise. The word "mighty" here means "the victorious, or the One who can make what He wills." "Wise" means controlling all creatures carefully and with their limits.
text.28:
This verse explains another parable given by Allah. The parable still revolves around the facts of human life itself, according to the level of their intellect. Thus, they can learn from the parable and assess Allah with all the attributes of perfection that are befitting to Him.

This verse explains a parable for those who worship several other gods besides Allah. They even prioritize loyalty to those gods over themselves.

In the parable, the polytheists of Mecca are told to pay attention to themselves and the position of themselves and the slaves they own. As masters, would they want to hand over all their possessions to those slaves and involve them in matters of wealth and pleasures that Allah has given them? Thus, the slaves become their rivals and partners in controlling that wealth and pleasure. Can the slave owners accept the provision that their slaves have power over what they own, so that they cannot do anything with their property before obtaining the consent and approval of their slaves? Of course, they would not be able to accept this. If that were acceptable, it would mean they no longer have full control over their wealth.

The issue occurs between two kinds of Allah's creatures, namely the masters and their slaves in managing and enjoying the sustenance, wealth, and blessings that He has bestowed upon them. The masters do not want to give in even a little to their slaves in controlling their wealth.

Allah, as the owner of everything, the All-Powerful and the All-Mighty, will not allow Himself to be associated by the polytheists with the creatures He created in the form of idols, just as they themselves would not want to associate with their slaves in managing and controlling their possessions. Anyone who uses a healthy mind and intellect will understand the parable. The actions of the polytheists are an insult to Allah.

Do the polytheists still hold to their belief that Allah has partners, while they hope for His mercy and fear His punishment, after this clear explanation and very strong argumentation? Some of them accept the argument, and some do not. Most of the polytheists have blind hearts and diseased souls, so they do not see the clear explanation and strong evidence.

This verse is closed with the sentence, "Thus do We explain the verses for a people who understand." Only those who use their minds can benefit from the holy verses of the Al-Qur'an and receive guidance and lessons from it.
text.29:
In this verse, Allah explains that the polytheists worship something other than Allah due to their own ignorance and foolishness. They are unwilling to pay attention to the clear explanations before them.

This verse is a parable for the polytheists who cannot benefit from Allah's detailed verses and extract wisdom from them. Instead, they remain in error and polytheism. Their minds are controlled and dominated by their desires. Such a person will never be controlled except by their own desires. They will not respond to anything except what aligns with the call of their devil.

The statement about performing an action without knowledge in this verse is an indication that the desires that control the polytheists are blind desires, impenetrable by the light of truth.

Sometimes, a person follows their desires. Then, when given a warning and guidance, they will rise up and follow that guidance. Such was the state of the polytheists who lived in the era of ignorant polytheism (jahiliyyah). They surrendered to their desires. However, when Islam came and the light of truth shone upon them, they awoke from their slumber. They could see after being blind, and received guidance after being astray.

This verse then concludes with the statement that those who have been led astray by Allah will never be guided. This statement is an indication to the stubborn polytheists that they remain in error. They will not move even a step away from that error, because Allah leaves them in that state. Allah says:

"Whomever Allah leaves astray - there is for him no guide. And He leaves them wandering blindly in their transgression." (al-A'raf/7: 186)

The polytheists will not accept guidance, so they live in error and die in error. When Allah's promise comes, they will stand to be reckoned and questioned. They will receive no reward other than Hellfire. There will be no helper for them.
text.30:
This verse commands the Prophet Muhammad to continue his task of conveying the message, leaving the stubborn polytheists in their error. In the phrase "So set your face toward the religion (of Islam), inclining to truth. (Adhere to) the fitrah of Allah," there is a command from Allah to the Prophet Muhammad to follow the straight religion, which is Islam, and to follow the *fitrah* of Allah. Some are of the opinion that the phrase means that Allah commands the Muslims to follow the religion of Allah that He has made for mankind. Here, "*fitrah*" is interpreted as "religion" because man was created to carry out that religion. This is reinforced by Allah's word in another surah:

And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me. (adz-dzariyat/51: 56)

To set one's face means to straighten one's purpose with all sincerity without turning to anything else. "Face" is specifically mentioned here because it is the place where all the senses gather, and the most honorable part of the body.

Regarding the word *fitrah* mentioned in this verse, there is an authentic hadith from Abu Hurairah which reads:

There is no child born except that he is born according to *fitrah*. It is his parents who make him a Jew, a Christian, or a Magian, just as an animal gives birth to its offspring in a perfect state. Do you feel any deficiency in it? Then Abu Hurairah said, "Recite this verse which means: ¦ the *fitrah* of Allah upon which He has created mankind. There is no change in the creation of Allah." In another narration, "Until you corrupt it (the animal)." The companions asked, "O Messenger of Allah, do you know the state of those who die in childhood?" The Messenger replied, "Allah knows best what they would have done." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

The scholars differ in opinion regarding the meaning of *fitrah*. Some are of the opinion that *fithrah* means "Islam." This was said by Abu Hurairah, Ibn Shihab, and others. They say that this opinion is well-known among the leading *salaf* who adhere to *ta'wil*. Their reason is verse (30) and the hadith of Abu Hurairah above. They also argue with the hadith that the Messenger of Allah (saw) said to the people one day:

Would you like me to tell you what Allah has told me in His Book? Verily, Allah created Adam and his descendants inclined to the truth and obedient to Allah. Allah gave them lawful wealth, not unlawful. Then they made the wealth given to them lawful and unlawful . . . "(Narrated by Ahmad from hammad)

The above opinion is adopted by most *tafsir* experts. As for the meaning of the Prophet's (saw) words when he was asked about the state of the children of the polytheists, he replied, "Allah knows best what they would have known," that is, if they were rational. This *ta'wil* is reinforced by the hadith of al-Bukhari from Samurah bin Jundub from the Prophet (saw). Part of the long hadith reads as follows:

As for the tall man in Paradise, he is Ibrahim (as). As for the children around him, they are all children born according to *fitrah*. Samurah said, "Then the Messenger of Allah was asked, 'O Messenger of Allah, about the children of the polytheists?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'And the children of the polytheists.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Samurah bin Jundub)

Some other scholars interpret "*fithrah*" as "the creation" by which Allah makes a child know his Lord. It is as if it is said, "Every child is born upon his creation." With that creation, the child will know his Lord when he has become rational and knowledgeable. This creation is different from the creation of animals that do not reach knowledge of their Lord. They argue that "*fithrah*" means "creation" and "*fathir*" means "the one who creates" with Allah's word:

Say, "O Allah, Creator of the heavens and the earth." (az-Zumar/39: 46)

And what reason do I have not to worship Him who created me. (Yasin/36: 22)

He (Ibrahim) answered, "Rather, your Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth, who created them." (al-Anbiya'/21: 56)

Then the sentence in verse (30) is continued with the expression that in the *fitrah* of Allah there is no change. Allah will not change His *fitrah*. Nothing violates that rule, meaning that those whom Allah has made happy will not be miserable, and conversely, those whom He has made miserable will not be happy. According to Mujahid, it means that there is no change for the religion of Allah. This opinion is supported by Qatadah, Ibn Jubair, adh-ahhak, Ibn Zaid, and an-Nakha'i. They are of the opinion that the above expression concerns belief. 'Ikrimah narrated from Ibn 'Abbas that Umar bin Khaththab said, "There is no change for Allah's creation from castrated animals." This statement means the prohibition of castrating animals.

The expression "that is the straight religion," according to Ibn 'Abbas, means "that is the straight decision." Muqatil said that that is the real calculation. Some say that the straight religion is the religion of Islam, but most people do not know. They do not want to think that the religion of Islam is the true religion. Therefore, they do not want to submit to their Creator, and the Lord who is more ancient (qadim) decides something and carries out His decision.
text.31:
This verse is a response to verse 30 of Surah ar-Rum above, which states, "There is no changing the religion of Allah." The meaning is that humans should never try to change the religion of Allah. How humans can avoid changing the religion of Islam is by repenting to Him. However, some interpret the phrase "by returning in repentance to Him" as an explanation of the phrase "set your face" mentioned above. The meaning is that Prophet Muhammad and his ummah should straighten their faces (set their faces) by returning in repentance to Allah. Muslims are also included in this command because a command to the Prophet (saw) also means a command to his ummah.

This verse also commands people to repent to Allah. This command is then connected to the command for people to be mindful of Him (taqwa), to establish prayer (salat), and the prohibition against being polytheists (mushrikun).

Returning to Allah is a good way to repair the fitrah (natural disposition) and avoid any obstacles that might hinder it.

The command to have taqwa is given precedence over the command to establish prayer because prayer is one of the fundamental signs of those who have taqwa. Prayer and other acts of worship will not be fruitful except on the basis of faith in Allah, feeling His power and sublimity. In this regard, Allah says:

Successful indeed are the believers, those who offer their Salat (prayers) with all solemnity and full submissiveness. (al-Mu'minun/23: 1-2)

Worship is also meaningless if it is not accompanied by sincerity (ikhlas). Therefore, this verse concludes with the necessity of sincerity in worship so that Muslims do not become polytheists (mushrikun).
text.32:
This verse is an explanation of the phrase "those who associate partners with Allah" mentioned in the previous verse (31). This verse commands Muslims not to become polytheists who are always in conflict and divide their religion, causing them to be split into several groups. They are always in disagreement because they adhere to a false religion, a religion created by humans.

This false religion has many forms, and its methods of worship also differ. Some worship idols, fire, angels, stars, the sun and moon, trees, graves, and so on. All of these are various types of gods worshipped by a group of polytheists. Each group has its own method of worship. They believe that they are the ones who are guided. They are very happy and proud of their group, even though they are a group that is at a loss and misguided.
text.33:
This verse explains a negative form of human behavior, which is that when afflicted with hardship, they draw near to Allah. Then, after the hardship disappears and is replaced with good fortune, they return to associating partners with Allah (shirk).

The hardship can be in the form of poverty, illness, calamity, disaster, and so on. The expression that the hardship only "touches" them means it is only light and momentary in their long life, not "overwhelming" them intensely. However, with just a slight touch of hardship, they already feel the world is dark. They immediately pray to Allah to be released from that hardship. They accompany that prayer by drawing near to Allah. They diligently worship, ask forgiveness for their sins, and promise to obediently carry out Allah's commands in the future. Thus, they return to their fitrah (natural disposition).

However, their obedience is only brief, that is, as long as the hardship is still felt. When Allah replaces that hardship by "giving them a taste" of just a little happiness, some of them become forgetful and return to associating partners with Allah (shirk). Associating partners with Allah means believing in the existence of other elements that play a role in making them fortunate or unfortunate, whether in the form of idols, devils, or humans. It is a great mistake if they view the profit of their business as the result of their own efforts and hard work, so that they do not give thanks for that blessing. They also do not use that blessing properly as desired by the Giver, Allah. Thus, they pollute their fitrah (natural disposition).
text.34:
This verse warns people who disbelieve in Allah, are impatient, and ungrateful, that blessings are His bounty. These blessings come from Allah, not from anyone else. Allah says:

"Do you not see that Allah has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth and has completed His favors upon you, [both] outwardly and inwardly? And of the people is he who disputes about Allah without knowledge or guidance or an illuminating Book." (Luqman/31:20)

Humans should not deny these blessings because there is no one besides Allah who can bestow such great blessings, as He says:

"This is the creation of Allah. So show Me what those other than Him have created. Rather, the wrongdoers are in clear error." (Luqman/31:11)

In this verse 34, Allah commands them, "Enjoy yourselves!" This command is a mockery of their disobedience. Thus, this command is not a real command, but a threat to stop their actions of worshiping and supplicating to others besides Allah and denying His blessings.

Moreover, the command to enjoy themselves is accompanied by the threat "you will soon know." Thus, they only enjoy this temporarily, at most for the remainder of their lives in this world. While in the Hereafter, they will receive terrible torment and punishment for their shirk and disbelief. Punishment can occur in this world, and certainly in the Hereafter. Thus, their disbelief in this world will not bring any benefit.

Therefore, before death comes, those who disbelieve by committing shirk and not being grateful for blessings should repent. Repentance should be done as soon as possible because repentance when the breath is already in the throat is not accepted by Allah, as happened to Pharaoh (see Surah Yunus/10: 90-91).
text.35:
Furthermore, Allah questions whether the polytheists possess a *sulthan* (proof or basis) originating from Allah that can justify their acts of *shirk*. A true belief must have a true foundation.

*Sulthan* literally means "real power that cannot be refuted." The intended meaning is a holy book and a messenger from Allah. A belief can only be called a religion if it possesses these elements in addition to God. The polytheistic belief of the Quraysh infidels was not based on revelation and was not taught by a prophet from Allah. This means that the belief is false.

Thus, the expression in the form of a question in that verse is once again intended as a denial or rejection. It is expressed in this way so that it penetrates sharply into the hearts of people. The *shirk* belief is misguided because it has no basis, was never taught by Allah, was never conveyed by His Messenger, and is not found in His holy book. Therefore, the *shirk* belief will be strictly examined by Allah, and its adherents will not escape His punishment, as stated in the following verse:

"And whoever invokes (or worships) besides Allah, any other *ilah* (god), of whom he has no proof; then his reckoning is only with his Lord. Surely! *Al-Kafirun* (the disbelievers in Allah and in the Oneness of Allah, polytheists, etc.) will not be successful." (al-Mu'minun/23: 117)

(36) The second behavior that can lead people to *shirk* is when they are given a little mercy by Allah, they become arrogant and forgetful. However, if they are afflicted with a little misfortune, they despair and then deny.

In this verse, Allah also states "tasting," which means that what is bestowed is only a little. This bounty includes material possessions. Therefore, no matter how much wealth one has, it is incomparable to the happiness that He will give in the Hereafter. However, some people are lulled by Allah's blessings in this world, then become arrogant and forgetful. They deny Allah and no longer heed all His commands and prohibitions. They are willing to sacrifice their eternal happiness in the Hereafter for insignificant and temporary pleasures in this world. As a result, they will be punished in the Hereafter.

Conversely, if they experience suffering caused by their own mistakes, they quickly despair. This part of the verse implies that the world is not always pleasant, but will be interspersed with difficulties. Happiness and sorrow are indeed alternated by Allah, as He says:

"And We shall make a trial of you with evil and good. And to Us you will be returned." (al-Anbiya'/21: 35)

Therefore, humans should not be quickly lulled when they receive blessings and should not quickly despair when they experience difficulties.

In this verse, it is stated that they despair because of the deeds of their own hands. This means that they committed the mistake intentionally. They should have acknowledged the mistake and quickly repented. But this is not the case; they distance themselves from Allah and do not ask for His help. Because they feel unable to face the difficulty, they despair and become pessimistic. Thus, they go against their *fitrah*, because those who stand on *fitrah* are those who always draw closer to Allah (see verse 31 above) and always remain optimistic.

This behavior is described in another verse:

"Verily, man (disbeliever) was created very impatient; Irritable (discontented) when evil touches him; And niggardly when good touches him. Except those devoted to *Salat* (prayers)." (al-Ma'arij/70: 19-22)

In these verses, it is explained that the behavior of being impatient, anxious, and stingy is the characteristic of some people, not all. Those who are consistent in performing *Salat* will not behave in this way, because they communicate with Allah at all times. Thus, they will not lose their minds when they experience difficulties and will not become arrogant when they receive blessings. They are patient when they experience difficulties and grateful when they receive happiness, as stated in the following hadith:

"Amazing is the affair of the believer, for Allah will not decree anything except that it is good for him. If he is afflicted with happiness, he is grateful, and that is good for him. If he is afflicted with misfortune, he is patient, and that is good for him." (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from Suhaib)
text.36:
Furthermore, Allah questions whether the polytheists possess a *sulthan* (proof or basis) originating from Allah that can justify their polytheistic actions. A true creed must have a true foundation.

*Sulthan* literally means "real power that cannot be refuted." The intended meaning is a holy book and a messenger from Allah. A belief can only be called a religion if it possesses those elements in addition to God. The polytheistic belief of the Quraysh disbelievers was not based on revelation and was not taught by a prophet from Allah. This means that belief is wrong.

Thus, the expression in the form of a question in that verse is once again meant as a denial or rejection. It is expressed in this way so that it penetrates sharply into the hearts of people. The polytheistic creed is misguided because it has no basis, was never taught by Allah, was never conveyed by His messenger, and is not found in His holy book. Therefore, that polytheistic creed will be strictly examined by Allah, and its adherents will not escape His punishment, as stated in the following verse:

And whoever invokes (or worships) besides Allah any other *ilah* (god), of whom he has no proof; then his reckoning is only with his Lord. Surely! *Al-Kafirun* (the disbelievers in Allah and in the Oneness of Allah, polytheists, etc.) will not be successful. (al-Mu'minun/23: 117)
text.37:
The behavior of quickly forgetting oneself when obtaining pleasure and despairing when obtaining hardship occurs because they distance themselves from Allah. As a result, they do not realize that it is Allah who regulates human sustenance. It is Allah who expands the sustenance of one person and withholds the sustenance of another according to His wisdom. The difference in sustenance occurs because of differences in ability, and differences in ability result in differences in human positions in life. Because of these differences in position, all fields of work can be filled by humans according to their abilities. Allah says:

"Is it they who would portion out the mercy of your Lord? It is We who have apportioned among them their livelihood in the life of this world and have raised some of them above others in degrees [of rank] that they may make use of one another. But the mercy of your Lord is better than whatever they accumulate." (az-Zukhruf/43:32)

This reality provides a lesson for those who believe that Allah exists and is All-Powerful and All-Wise. Both the abundance and limitation of sustenance are tests from Allah, whether those given sustenance are able to use it according to what Allah wills, and whether those whose sustenance is limited are able to realize their limitations.

In addition, Allah's blessings are not only material, but also non-material, such as health, peace of mind, a good reputation, and so on. It often happens that Allah pours out material blessings on someone, but limits non-material blessings. Conversely, Allah often limits material blessings to someone, but pours out His non-material blessings. This shows that Allah is All-Powerful and All-Wise, so humans should believe in Him.
text.38:
This verse is an explanation of verse 37, which states that those who have been given excess sustenance by Allah must help those who are in need. This assistance takes the form of material aid beyond zakat. Those who are prioritized for assistance are close family members. In this verse, this assistance is even stated as their right. In another verse, it is stated that if we are unable to help, then this needs to be conveyed honestly with words that are easy to accept and soothing:

And if you turn away from them awaiting mercy from your Lord which you expect, then speak to them a gentle word. (al-Isra'/17:28)

Those who need help are the poor, namely those who are unable to meet their basic needs. Thus, Allah does not want any of His creatures to starve, let alone die from starvation. If this happens, then those who have excess sustenance are sinful. Indeed, one can feel how painful hunger is and understand how dangerous starvation is.

Furthermore, those who need help are stranded travelers, at least for one day. With assistance after assistance, they will be able to reach their place of origin. Returning a traveler to their place of origin immediately will be of great benefit, because they will be able to work again as before. Leaving them stranded in a foreign place will cause various problems in that place.

Such is the obligation of a believer. They are aware that the wealth they possess is merely a trust entrusted to them to be managed well. The owner of the wealth is Allah, so when the owner asks for a portion to be given out to help others, they will not refuse. Allah says:

Believe in Allah and His Messenger and spend [in the way of Allah] from that of which He has made you successors. For those who have believed among you and spent, there will be a great reward. (al-hadid/57: 7)

A believer will not consider that the wealth they possess is solely obtained through their own efforts. All the good fortune that humans obtain is a gift from Allah, as stated in the Qur'an about Prophet Sulaiman:

One who had knowledge of the Scripture said, "I will bring it to you before your glance returns [to you]." And when he [Solomon] saw it placed before him, he said, "This is from the favor of my Lord to test me whether I will be grateful or ungrateful. And whoever is grateful - his gratitude is only for [the benefit of] himself. And whoever is ungrateful - then indeed, my Lord is Free of need and Generous." (an-Naml/27: 40)

An attitude that negates Allah's favor in every good fortune is the attitude of Qarun, a very wealthy but disobedient man in the time of Prophet Musa a.s. As a result, he and his wealth were swallowed by the earth. Allah says:

He said, "I was only given it because of knowledge I have." Did he not know that Allah had destroyed before him of generations those who were greater than him in power and greater in accumulation [of wealth]? But the criminals, about their sins they will not be asked. (al-Qashash/28: 78)

Helping close family, the poor, and stranded travelers will have a good impact on both the giver and the receiver. The giver means they have fulfilled Allah's command, so they will be loved by Him. Meanwhile, the receiver will feel helped, and therefore, *silaturrahim* (kinship ties) will be established between families who are well-off and those who are in need. The impact is security and close brotherhood.

Such an impact will be obtained if the giver gives only for the sake of seeking Allah's pleasure. Thus, the meaning of this verse excerpt is that the giver gives not to expect a reward from the receiver, but a reward from Allah when they face Him later in the afterlife. That is, they give sincerely. Believers are forbidden from giving because of *ria*, which is to be seen by people or to show off. One form of *ria* is giving but mentioning the gift to others, thereby degrading the name of the receiver, or hurting the receiver's feelings by conveying words or actions that wound their feelings. Allah says:

O you who have believed, do not invalidate your charities with reminders or injury, like one who spends his wealth [only] to be seen by the people and does not believe in Allah and the Last Day. His example is like that of a smooth stone upon which is dust and is hit by a downpour that leaves it bare. They are unable [to claim] anything from what they have earned. And Allah does not guide the disbelieving people. (al-Baqarah/2: 264)
text.39:
This verse explains *riba* that is intended as a gift or giving to gain more. *Riba* is the return of more than the debt. This excess is sometimes intended as a gift, with the hope that the gift will grow in the hands of the lender, and then that person will reciprocate by giving the debtor more than what was gifted to them. Such *riba* was often practiced in the pre-Islamic era (Jahiliyyah). This verse affirms that such business behavior does not receive blessings from Allah. It does not receive reward from Him because the giving is not sincere. Therefore, scholars view this verse as the first verse in the stage of prohibiting *riba* until its explicit prohibition. (The second stage is in Surah an-Nisa'/4: 161, which contains an indication of the prohibition of *riba*; the third stage is Ali 'Imran/3: 130, that only *riba* that is multiplied is prohibited; the fourth stage is al-Baqarah/2: 278, which prohibits *riba* completely in any form).

There are also those who understand this verse to be about giving to someone with the intention of obtaining a greater reward. This greater reward includes the repayment of debt. That is what is called *riba* in the verse above, and many scholars permit it based on the hadith:

The Messenger of Allah received gifts and reciprocated them. He reciprocated the gift of a milking camel that was given to him, and he did not deny the owner when he asked for reciprocation. He only denied the anger of the gift-giver because the reciprocation was worth more than the value of the gift. (Narrated by al-Bukhari from 'Aisyah)

However, based on that hadith, what is actually justified is reciprocating a gift with more, not paying a debt more than it should be.

Giving with the intention of obtaining a greater reward than what is given indicates insincerity on the part of the giver. This is also not justified. Allah says:

And do not confer favor that you seek a greater return. (al-Muddassir/74: 6)

One form of giving that is intended to obtain a greater reward is giving with the intention that the person will be obedient to the giver, willing to help him, and so on. That is also not justified, because it is not sincere.

Outwardly, the prohibition in that verse is addressed to the Prophet (saw). However, it is also intended for his entire ummah.

As for what Allah will multiply, both in reward and in wealth itself, is giving sincerely, which in this verse is expressed by the term *zakat* (literally meaning pure). *Zakat* here means voluntary charity (sadaqah), not obligatory *zakat*. A person who gives charity hoping for reward from Allah will surely have his reward or recompense multiplied by Allah at least seven hundred times, as He says in al-Baqarah/2: 261:

The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a seed [of grain] which grows seven spikes; in each spike is a hundred grains. And Allah multiplies [His reward] for whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing. (al-Baqarah/2: 261)

In addition, charity will also multiply the wealth of the capital owner, because it strengthens the purchasing power of the wider community. The strong purchasing power of the community will demand increased production. Increased production will demand an increase in production institutions (factories, companies, etc.). The increase in production institutions will open up employment opportunities, which will automatically demand an increase in labor. The increase in labor will increase community income, thereby increasing their purchasing power, and so on. Thus, there is a cycle of increasing purchasing power, production, labor, and so on, so that an economy based on the empowerment of the wider community will always increase economic progress. Meanwhile, an economy based on *riba*, namely the return of more than the debt, always contains exploitation, which will gradually set back the economy.
text.40:
This verse returns to discussing the omnipotence of Allah. If the previous verses concerned the determination of sustenance (rizq), the following verses concern the course of human life. The goal is for humans to want to do good, including giving charity (sedekah) as Allah commanded in the previous verse.

In this verse, it is stated that Allah created humans from nothing into existence, then they appear in this world. To be able to live in the world, He also provides them with sustenance. After that, humans will die and will be resurrected. This return to life has already begun in the grave (alam barzakh) until the Day of Judgment. After the Day of Judgment, humans will be resurrected forever.

The condition of life after death depends greatly on the actions of humans in the world. If their actions are good, they will be happy, and if their actions are bad, they will be punished. Therefore, humans should obey Allah's provisions regarding the sustenance He has given. They should obtain it correctly according to Allah's provisions, not from usury (riba). If that sustenance is more than enough, it should be used to help those in need.

Then Allah asks if there are other gods who are able to do things like the above. Let alone creating complex humans, creating even a simple creature from something that is completely non-existent, humans will not be able to. Can humans create even a grain of sand, or a single leaf from nothing? Therefore, Allah affirms, "Glorified and Exalted is He above all that they associate with Him." Thus, humans should stop deifying anything other than Allah or associating partners with Him (shirk).
text.41:
In this verse, it is explained that *al-fasad* has occurred on land and sea. *Al-Fasad* is any form of violation of the system or laws made by Allah, which is translated as "destruction." This destruction can take the form of environmental pollution that makes it uninhabitable, or even the destruction of nature so that it can no longer be utilized. On land, for example, the destruction of flora and fauna, and in the sea, the damage to marine biota. Also included in *al-fasad* are robbery, piracy, murder, rebellion, and so on.

This destruction occurs as a result of human behavior, such as excessive exploitation of nature, wars, weapons testing, and so on. This behavior is impossible for someone who believes with true faith because he knows that all his actions will be accounted for before Allah.

In this verse, Allah affirms that not all the bad consequences of environmental destruction are felt by humans, but only some of them. Some other bad consequences have been overcome by Allah, including by providing systems in nature that can neutralize or restore environmental damage. This means that Allah is merciful to humans. If Allah were not merciful to humans, and did not provide natural systems to restore the damage, then surely humans would feel all the consequences of their evil deeds. The entire universe would be damaged and humans would no longer be able to inhabit and utilize it, so they would be destroyed. Allah says:

And if Allah were to punish men for their wrongdoing, He would not leave on earth a single moving (living) creature, but He defers them for an appointed term. And when their term comes, then verily, Allah is Ever All-Seer of His slaves. (al-Fathir/35: 45)

By inflicting upon them some of the consequences of the environmental destruction they have committed, Allah hopes that humans will become aware. They will no longer damage the environment, but will preserve it. They will no longer violate the ecosystem created by Allah, but will obey it. They will also no longer deny and associate partners with Allah, but will believe in Him. Indeed, polytheism is an extraordinarily great sin with terrible consequences that are difficult for the perpetrator to bear. It is even difficult for the universe to bear, as stated in His word:

That the heavens are almost torn, and the earth is split asunder, and the mountains fall in ruins. (Maryam/19: 90)

The entire heavens and earth are one system united under the command of Allah. As mentioned in the Qur'an, everything in this system is given for the benefit of human life, which is followed by a spiritual warning not to associate partners with Him.

As caliphs, humans must follow and obey all of Allah's laws, including not causing damage to existing natural resources. They must also be responsible for the sustainability of life on this earth. The earth is subjected by Allah to be a place of residence for humans. However, instead of being grateful, humans have become the creatures that most often disrupt the balance of nature. Examples of natural events that occur in the homeland due to human actions are forest fires and floods.

With the appointment of humans as caliphs, in addition to obtaining the right to use what is on earth, they also bear a heavy responsibility in managing it. From this, we can see the Islamic view that the earth is indeed intended for humans. However, humans must not treat the earth as they please. This is indicated by the word earth (453 times) which is mentioned more often in the Qur'an than heaven or paradise (320 times). This gives a strong impression of the goodness and sanctity of the earth. Dust can replace water in purification. The Prophet Muhammad saw said:

The earth has been made for me as a masjid and as a means of purification. (Narrated by Abu Dawud and Ibn Majah from Abu Hurairah)

There is a kind of sacredness and sanctity from the earth, so it is a good place to worship God, both in formal ceremonies and in everyday life.
text.42:
In this verse, Allah asks Prophet Muhammad to convey to the polytheists of Mecca to travel wherever they may on earth to witness the destruction experienced by the disbelieving peoples of the past. They are now only ruins or names without a trace. This should be a lesson for them that Allah can destroy them if they remain disbelievers.

This command also applies to anyone after them until the end of time. If they doubt the truth of Islam, let them witness with their own eyes those ruins or examine their historical relics. Those peoples were destroyed because of their denial of Allah, and for causing chaos against fellow humans and the environment. That destruction is a result of the bad impact of their own deeds.
text.43:
So that such destruction does not happen to humans again, Allah asks Prophet Muhammad and anyone who wants to be saved to turn their faces to the "upright religion." The meaning of "upright religion" here is Islam because this religion brings teachings that are straight and certainly lead to happiness in this world and the hereafter. The command to turn the face means to fully carry out those teachings. The mention of the face in this verse is because it represents the identity of a person. Directing the face means directing all aspects of a person, namely physical, spiritual, and intellectual. Turning the face to the upright religion means carrying out religious commands with complete totality.

The implementation of these teachings must be as soon as possible so that society becomes better, safer, and more developed. Those who are guilty must immediately realize and repent. This is because the age of humans and this universe is limited. When death comes to a person or the Day of Judgment occurs for mankind, then no one can reject it, as Allah says:

And for every nation there is a [specified] term. So when their term has come, they will not remain behind an hour, nor will they precede [it]. (al-A'raf/7: 34)

At the end of this verse, it is depicted that on the Day of Resurrection, where everyone is resurrected, all humans are in an uproar and running around aimlessly. Each is busy with their own problems, as described in the following verses:

That is the Day a man will flee from his brother, and his mother and his father, and his wife and his children, for every man, that Day, will have enough to make him heedless [of others]. ('Abasa/80: 34-37)

Humans are only guided by their deeds. Therefore, humans at that time will be patterned into two groups, as stated in the following verse.
text.44:
This verse informs us of the existence of two groups of people: those who disbelieve and those who are good. Those who disbelieve and commit sins must be held accountable for their disbelief and sins. They will be examined before a most just court, so that even the smallest of their evil deeds will surely be presented and the punishment will be conveyed.

On the other hand, there is the group of good people. Even the smallest of their good deeds will surely be presented before that court, and then they will be rewarded. That person means that, with their good deeds, they have spread out a path or "carpet" for themselves to walk on towards paradise.

The classification of humans into two groups, the first entering paradise and the other entering hell, is also mentioned in another verse:

And thus We have revealed to you an Arabic Qur'an that you may warn the Mother of Cities (Makkah) and those around it and warn of the Day of Gathering, of which there is no doubt. A party will be in Paradise and a party in the Blaze. (ash-Shura/42: 7)
text.45:
Those who will receive a good reward from Allah are those who believe and do good deeds. This means that faith is demonstrated by good deeds, and the reward is Paradise. However, the reward itself is not an absolute and deserved recompense for the good deeds of humans. The good deeds of humans are not sufficient and not yet worthy of being rewarded with Paradise full of unparalleled blessings. Therefore, the Paradise received by humans who do good is a gift from Allah, not a reward for their deeds. Thus, the attainment of Paradise is because Allah loves those who believe, and does not love those who disbelieve.

The expression in this verse is indeed very concise, but comprehensive. Concise because the opposite of what is conveyed is not stated. This verse only expresses that, "Allah rewards those who believe and do good deeds" and, "He does not love those who disbelieve." From these two expressions are contained two other expressions that mean the opposite, namely, "He punishes those who disbelieve and do evil" and "He loves those who believe and do good." The opposite expression does not need to be stated because it can be understood from the first expression. Thus, this verse states that Allah rewards those who believe and do good with Paradise and loves them, and Allah gives a reward in the form of Hell for those who disbelieve and do evil and hates them.
text.46:
This verse explains that among the signs of Allah's omnipotence is the wind, which provides great benefits to humans in four ways: as good tidings, bringing mercy, facilitating navigation, and enabling the pursuit of Allah's bounty.

The wind is a precursor or sign of coming rain. This is because the wind forms clouds. When these clouds become denser and cooler, they turn into water droplets and then fall as rain. Thus, the wind brings good news to humans, namely the possibility of rain.

Through this rain, Allah wants to bestow His mercy upon humanity. Rain provides water, which is the source of life for plants, animals, and humans themselves. It is an adage in science that where there is water, there is life; where there is no water, there is no life. Because there is water, plants and animals "which are staple foods for humans" can live. Because there is water, agriculture and animal husbandry can also be developed. Therefore, humans need to preserve water sources and manage rainwater well so that it is not wasted into the sea.

Another use of the wind mentioned in this verse is for navigation. From the era of sailing ships to the era of motor ships, and even to the era of nuclear-powered ships today, weather and wind are still determining or influential factors in the success of navigation. The wind blows by Allah's command, in the sense that it is based on the laws He has determined. Therefore, humans need to develop meteorology, which studies wind, weather, and so on, so that navigation is smooth and advanced.

A further use of the wind is to seek Allah's bounty. Therefore, various technologies for utilizing wind need to be developed, in addition to agriculture, animal husbandry, and navigation mentioned above. Currently, humans are developing the use of wind as an energy source, for example, for power generation, driving machines, and so on. Therefore, meteorology needs to be strengthened so that it is beneficial for agriculture, animal husbandry, navigation, energy, industry, and other economic activities. With the development of economic activities, prosperity will increase.

The existence of wind and the laws created by Allah for the welfare of mankind should be gratefully acknowledged. They should acknowledge the existence of Allah, believe in Him, acknowledge that sustenance is His bounty, use sustenance according to His will, and obediently worship Him. If humans are grateful, then it is for themselves, as stated in the following verse:

And We had certainly given Luqman wisdom, [saying], "Be grateful to Allah." And whoever is grateful is grateful for [the benefit of] himself. And whoever denies - then indeed, Allah is Free of need and Praiseworthy. (Luqman/31: 12)

For those who are grateful for His blessings, Allah will add more blessings to them, as stated in the following verse:

And [remember] when your Lord proclaimed, 'If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe.' (Ibrahim/14: 7)
text.47: Just as the wind sent by Allah is of great benefit to mankind, so too are the messengers that Allah has sent to them. They certainly bring even greater benefit to mankind, because they bring clear proofs from Allah in the form of His revelation containing teachings. If these teachings are implemented by mankind, they will provide extraordinary benefits. However, many people deny them, so in this world they are afflicted by the consequences of their own evil deeds, and in the Hereafter Allah will cast them into Hell. Conversely, for those who believe, Allah has obligated Himself to help by saving them from the evil and negative impact of the evil of the disbelievers. In the Hereafter, Allah will reward their faith and good deeds with Paradise.
text.48:
In this verse, Allah affirms that He is the One who causes the winds to blow, by creating laws in the air. Among these is that air from areas of high pressure flows to areas of low pressure, thus creating wind. The blowing of the wind is an initial sign of the coming of rain.

According to scientists, the occurrence of rain is a cycle. Therefore, it does not matter from where the explanation begins. Water flows along streams that will join other streams to form much larger rivers. The river eventually flows into the sea. While water flows through streams and rivers, some will evaporate due to the heat of the sun (turning into gas), but most continues to flow to the sea. It is in the sea that the process of evaporation continues.

All the water that evaporates, whether from streams, rivers, or the sea, forms water vapor in the atmosphere. This vapor rises and cools as it reaches the higher atmosphere. If there are many gases in the atmosphere, it will condense into clouds that we can see. If the cloud reaches an even higher part of the atmosphere, the water vapor turns into ice droplets.

When clouds cross highlands or when they become colder due to lower atmospheric temperatures, the water becomes solid and falls. Initially, the water is still like very small droplets, then it usually melts before reaching the ground, and then falls to earth as rain.

Allah sends down rain in the place He wills, namely in areas afflicted by drought. People in the place where rain falls are certainly happy because they regain a source of life that will revive all living things.
text.49: That joy will be felt intensely by someone who has long experienced drought. The absence of rain for a long time makes people despair. That despair immediately vanishes as soon as the rain falls. Therefore, they should believe and be grateful.
text.50:
Such is the mercy of Allah towards mankind. Allah asks Prophet Muhammad and all his followers to see how the mercy of Allah in the form of rain affects the earth. Land that was once dead, dry, and barren becomes alive, loose, and fertile, thus growing all kinds of plants. Allah affirms that this event is an indication that Allah is able to resurrect mankind in the Hereafter after death. In the Qur'an, it is explained that with just one blowing of the trumpet, all living beings will die on the Day of Judgment. Then with another blowing, all will come back to life, both those who died before the Day of Judgment and those who died on the Day of Judgment itself. Allah says:

"And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on." (az-Zumar/39: 68)

How the reality of the Day of Judgment and the resurrection will be cannot be known for certain, because it is a part of the unseen (ghaib) that cannot be known concretely now. Humans only need to believe that Allah is able to realize all of that because He is All-Powerful.
text.51: This verse presents a hypothetical situation: what if Allah sent a scorching, dry wind that turned their previously lush crops yellow and withered? They would surely increase in their disbelief in Allah. Even when Allah sends rain-bearing winds that make their crops flourish, they only rejoice and do not give thanks to Him. How much more so if what was sent was that dry wind. The death of their previously fertile crops would cause them to grumble and increase in their disbelief in Allah.
text.52:
Allah affirms to Prophet Muhammad that he will not be able to instill guidance into the hearts of those who disbelieve until that person turns away from disbelief and then believes. To illustrate this, Allah gives an example of a blind person who is lost. A blind person cannot possibly find the way, because he does not see it, unless he is guided. Likewise, is the person who has chosen disbelief and polytheism (shirk). That person's heart is already closed. Therefore, whatever guidance is conveyed to him, he will not listen to it or follow it. For them, whether they are shown guidance or not, it is the same; they will not believe. The only One who can open their hearts is Allah, if He wills. However, He will not will it if the person concerned does not strive, because that would violate the laws that He has established. This verse thus reminds the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) once again not to be disappointed if there are people who reject his da'wah (call to Islam).

The only ones who will accept when guided by the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) are those who believe. This is because their hearts are open to receiving all the truth conveyed to them. After accepting the truth, they implement it wholeheartedly to dedicate themselves to Him.
text.53:
Such is the hardness of the hearts of some people, namely those who are disbelievers and polytheists. Blessings do not soften their hearts, and curses do not make them repent. They are likened to the dead or the deaf. The dead do not hear anything that is said to them. Likewise, the deaf who run helter-skelter will not hear the calls directed at them. Therefore, Allah reminds the Prophet Muhammad that no matter how hard he tries to awaken such people, it will not succeed unless Allah permits it, and therefore the Prophet should not be disappointed.

(53) Allah affirms to the Prophet Muhammad that he will not be able to instill guidance into the hearts of those who disbelieve until that person turns away from disbelief and then believes. For this, Allah gives an example of a blind person who is lost. A blind person cannot find the way because he does not see it, unless he is guided. Likewise, is the person who has chosen disbelief and polytheism. That person's heart is already closed. Therefore, whatever guidance is conveyed to him will not be heard or followed. For them, whether they are shown guidance or not, it is the same; they will not believe. Only Allah can open their hearts if He wills. However, He will not will it if the person concerned does not strive, because that violates the laws that He has established. This verse thus reminds the Prophet (saw) once again not to be disappointed if there are people who reject his da'wah (call to Islam).

The only people who will accept when guided by the Prophet (saw) are those who believe. This is because their hearts are open to receiving all the truth that is conveyed to them. After accepting the truth, they carry it out wholeheartedly to devote themselves to Him.
text.54: In this verse, the journey of human life is conveyed. They originate from something insignificant and powerless, namely a *nuthfah* (zygote) which is an egg fertilized by sperm. That *nuthfah* then develops into a fetus, and is then born, as informed in al-Mu'minun/23:12-14. From childhood, humans then become adolescents, adults, then mature, and become powerful and mighty individuals. After that, humans enter old age. In old age, humans become weak creatures again. Besides being weak, humans also experience physical changes, including hair that was once black turning gray, skin becoming wrinkled, eyesight and hearing becoming weaker, and other changes. After that, humans will certainly die. Thus, Allah creates whomever He wills, meaning that the journey of human life in the world is generally like that. However, Allah can determine otherwise, namely that humans can die at ages He wills before that old age. Such is the weakness of humans before God. Therefore, they should not be arrogant, but believe and be obedient to Him.
text.55:
It is explained that on the Day of Resurrection, the disbelievers will declare to Allah that the life they lived in the world was very short. They will ask to be returned to the world and promise to improve their deeds. They will convey this to Allah by swearing an oath. Thus, their habit of lying in the world is still carried over to the afterlife. Their statements and promises are merely *helah* (excuses) for them to avoid Allah's punishment. If they were returned to the world, they would surely return to disbelief and do evil, as stated in the following verse:

"But (in fact) what they concealed before has [now] become evident to them. And if they were returned [to the world], they would surely revert to that which they were forbidden. And indeed, they are liars." (al-An'am/6: 28)

They were indeed given sufficient opportunity in the world to do what they should have, but they were negligent, tempted by Satan, and did evil. They acknowledge this as depicted in the following verse:

"And on the Day when He will gather them - [it will be] as if they had not remained [in the world] but an hour of a day, [during which] they will recognize one another. Those will have lost who deny the meeting with Allah, and they were not guided." (Yunus/10: 45)

Therefore, the brevity of life in the world in the feelings of the disbelievers is merely a fabricated excuse. In reality, they are afraid of entering hell, so they seek various kinds of *helah* or deceptions.
text.56: The feeling of the disbelievers that their life in the world is very short is not true. It is their attempt to lie before Allah. Their lie is refuted by those who are granted knowledge and faith. Those who are granted knowledge are those who understand the essence of truth, then believe and prove their faith with good deeds, so that they truly feel what they believe in their hearts. Those who are granted faith are those who have obtained the essence of truth, so they believe in Allah and everything revealed in the Qur'an. They also carry out all the commands of revelation to prepare themselves for the Day of Resurrection. Those who have been given knowledge and faith fill their lives with good deeds as preparation for facing the Day of Resurrection. Therefore, they do not feel that their life in the world is short, but sufficient. The disbelievers feel their lives are short because they are negligent in the world. They assume that life in the world is not connected to the afterlife, and do not realize that all their actions must be accounted for.
text.57:
On the Day of Resurrection, humans will be brought before the court of Allah. At that time, disbelievers will not be permitted to offer any excuses, such as feeling that their lives in the world were too short and requesting to be returned to the world for even a moment to do good deeds. They will also not be given any opportunity to have their punishment changed. In another verse, Allah says:

And if you could but see when the criminals are hanging their heads before their Lord, [saying], "Our Lord, we have seen and heard, so return us [to the world] that we may do righteousness. Indeed, we are [now] certain." And if We had willed, We could have given every soul its guidance, but the word from Me has come into effect that I will surely fill Hell with jinn and men all together. (as-Sajdah/32:12-13)
text.58: In this verse, it is stated that Allah has conveyed various explanations about the evidence that He exists and is All-Powerful. Among these are how previous communities and their civilizations were destroyed for violating Allah's provisions, how He sends down rain that has a great influence on fertility and prosperity, and how He determines the course of human life until death and resurrection in the afterlife. All of this shows that Allah is All-Powerful, and at the same time shows that the return to life in the afterlife exists. However, those who do not want to believe deny all of this as a sign of Allah's existence and His omnipotence. They even accuse those who believe of conveying falsehoods and committing lies.
text.59: The rejection of the disbelievers towards every explanation from Allah conveyed by Prophet Muhammad is because their hearts have been sealed by Allah. This sealing of the heart occurred because they themselves always closed it off to every verse or truth conveyed to them, until finally the heart was truly sealed. They did not want to understand and did not want to comprehend the essence of the truth conveyed to them and they were arrogant, ultimately leading them to disbelief (kufr).
text.60: Allah asked Prophet Muhammad to be patient in the face of the disbelievers whose hearts were sealed, who denied Allah and the Hereafter, and who accused the believers of conveying and committing falsehoods. This was because Allah's promise is true, the Hereafter is certain, and those who disbelieve and commit shirk will surely be cast into Hell. Therefore, the Prophet and the Muslims should not be confused and agitated by the denial and refutation of these disbelievers. The Prophet was asked to be steadfast and not to stop conveying the da'wah and implementing the truth of the Al-Qur'an.
